Advocating for Alternative User Journeys.source_text: I worry it might lead to a very un-usable experience for a screen-reader user. The move-up/down buttons do not make sense out of context. They'll only hear 'Move up' or 'Move down,' but the function or feature it refers to remains unclear to them.
Tabbing down instead of across is preferred and was changed in Moodle 3.1 in 2015.
[~jverdaguer] is the "mode" in each of these necessary? just wondering if "View - Course: [Course name]" would be a little more susinct for screen readers particularly. "Mode" is implied
it also breaks native keyboard scrolling of the page content which affects all keyboard users I guess.
if you shrink the screen down to show the more menu within the secondary navigation and toggle the dropdown
I agree that keyboard controls should work here.
Tested with voiceover, it worked, meaning that users from macOS can also benefit from this fix.
I'm on the opinion that this patch does not go deep enough. What happens if you name a Block & ' ¬¢ ¬£ ¬© ‚Ç¨ ¬• ¬Æ < > ? You do not want the screen reader to read out 'lt', 'gt' or 'amp', do you?
Screen-reader users do not see/hear anything about a grade being a pass or fail grade. We must not convey information through colour alone.
if the dropdown menu is shown via keyboard, the first item should receive highlight/focus.
JAWS treats long alt text as multiple images on the page, So one image with 200 + chars, it truncates.
I tried Test 2 on a Mac (using inbuilt accessibility reader which is perhaps a bit clunkier than others?) - it only picked up the second event I created
With your patch, folks with screen readers will need to know that they have to go to the top of the page to see the list of errors.
If you are using a screen reader you hear a series of button states but are left with no idea what they are for.
When accessing notification preferences the settings are not keyboard accessible - I can't use tab to reach checkboxes

When I use screenreader on notifications settings page no matter if checkbox is checked or not it always reads is as 'checkbox not checked'. I believe it would be very confusing for screenreader users.
Colour-blind users do not use screen readers. So using aria attributes are not going to help them at all.
When modal dialogs open, focus should move inside them automatically, otherwise keyboard-only users get lost.
Using only hover to reveal content excludes touch users and those relying on keyboard navigation.
If error messages only appear visually, screen reader users won‚Äôt know how to correct their input.
Timed quizzes without pause or extension options create barriers for users needing extra processing time.
Relying on drag-and-drop alone prevents keyboard users from completing the activity.
Links labeled only 'click here' provide no context for screen reader users skimming through a page.
Colour-only indicators in grade reports mean colour-blind users can‚Äôt distinguish results.
Without skip-to-content links, keyboard users must tab through every navigation item before reaching main content.
Expandable menus should announce their state, otherwise screen reader users don‚Äôt know if they are open or closed.
Users navigating by headings expect a logical order, but inconsistent heading levels disrupt the journey.

Applying External Standards and Principl.source_text: I would recommend having this approach consulted with AbleDocs if this would be sufficient to pass the accessibility issue that was raised.
Deque's web accessibility checklist for Language recommends the use of a standard two-character ISO 639-1 code

we have more or less come to the concensus that the notice should be at the top of the page within the DOM but rendered at the bottom as it currently is. This is inline with examples such as deque (https://deque.com/) which we use as a reference alot and nngroup (https://www.nngroup.com/articles/modal-nonmodal-dialog/).
I'd also heavily suggest referring to the menubar portion of the w3 accessibility guidelines
According to https://www.w3schools.com/jsref/prop_pushbutton_type.asp in the absence of an explicit type="..." attribute, most browsers will assume type="submit" for button elements
+1 for the role="application" change. Well done for finding that recommendation.
Under SC 1.4.13 Content on Hover or Focus, If hover or focus causes content changes, we need to make sure the introduced interaction is predictable.
WCAG 2.1 SC 2.5.3 Label in Name: ensure the accessible name contains the visible label text so voice-control users can activate the control by speaking it.

This is not a hard problem to fix properly but applying colour in this fashion, which is inaccessible to a very large number of people, is not a suitable approach. We must not convery information through colour alone, and we should not introduce new technical debt with the approach of "we'll fix it tomorrow", or "someone else's problem".
Huong referred to the Using ARIA trees (https://www.w3.org/WAI/GL/wiki/Using_ARIA_trees) documentation
this might help: https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-practices-1.1/examples/menu-button/menu-button-links.html
We're also looking at https://webaim.org/techniques/alttext/#complex
according to [https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-1.1/#aria-hidden] aria-hidden="false" behaves inconsistently across browsers.
https://www.w3.org/WAI/GL/wiki/Using_aria-labelledby_to_provide_a_name_for_user_interface_controls
The WCAG 2.1 success criteria require visible focus indicators that meet a minimum contrast ratio.
Per WCAG 2.1.1 Keyboard, all interactive elements must be operable via keyboard alone.
WCAG requires that electronic forms provide labels that are programmatically associated.
Following Nielsen Norman Group heuristics, error recovery should guide users rather than punish them.
According to ARIA Authoring Practices, tree views must announce expanded and collapsed states.
WCAG techniques G18 and G145 recommend avoiding color combinations that fail the 4.5:1 ratio.
Per 1.4.10 Reflow, content must work at 320 CSS px (‚âà400% zoom) without loss of information or horizontal scrolling; fix table and sidebar overflow.
WCAG Name, Role, Value requires custom widgets to expose an accessible name/role and update states (e.g., aria-pressed) so AT reflects changes.

Interpreting Automated Tooling.source_text: Interestingly, axe DevTools and Nu HTML Validator don't really complain about missing legend tags.
Looking at you screenshots, it seems you are encountering this contrast warning within the accessibility checker (Brickfield labs) that we bought in recently, Would this be correct?
I think that the Brickfield labs accessibility checker is a bit overzealous in this case.
Errors found in Axe do not related to the configured external tool.
I know div inside label is a technical error from WAVE, but does it acually matter? Why don't we just ignore this? (and file a bug on the spec)
We use ARC Toolkit to test accessibility and the result is the same as Axe.
Wave and axe disagree on the same table headers, one flags them as missing while the other says they are fine.
WAVE suggests adding alt text everywhere, even for purely decorative icons.
The automated checker shows dozens of ARIA role errors, but in practice they don‚Äôt affect screen reader behavior.
ARC Toolkit flagged contrast issues that weren‚Äôt visible to users.
Contrast audits between ARC and AXE tool.
WAVE flags an aria-expanded mismatch in the static HTML (aria-expanded="false") runtime testing with NVDA confirms the expanded state is announced

Problem Identification and Validation.source_text: it seems that these changes are causing Behat failures in all branches

Hey, this has caused a pretty unwelcome change on a bunch of our sites: I know there is a variable to control it, but it's not ideal that this has affected basically every page of some of our sites with no warning.

this isn't workable solution. can we please reopen this issue and look to revert it. I've just reviewed the patch and it will break 100% of themes where the page background colour doesn't match the headder colour and takes zero consideration of the actual colour of the headder text, making the contrast far worse in many cases where default text colours are used.
I've created https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-83047 for this to be addressed (as a priority, if possible üôè)
I managed to reproduce it on a 4.4 instance ([https://sandbox.moodledemo.net/)] only for Quiz (not forum for example) and I agree this can be an issue for accessibility.

I was also able to reproduce this in Moodle 4.0.5.

When I am grading posts in Moodle, I frequently give students anonymous feedback via replies. Whenever I post a reply, Moodle will jump me back to the top of the page, which means I have to scroll back down to wherever I was in my grading process. This was not the case with the old version. Perhaps we should stick to the design in the old version.
page scroll position to be lost and the page to load back at the top.
it seems that there are four consistent failures in all branches with this patch applied
we are seeing some consistent behat failures which seems to be caused by some of the changes in the core elements
we are still seeing some failures that might be caused by these changes
I'm not 100% sure, but I think they may have caused a regression with the password mask field.

yes this is known issue affecting elements in group. Linking to WP-2594 to get this addressed

yes, confirming that this is the issue that we need to fix in MDL, on 3.10 it only affects Moodle Workplace

MDL-80198 was detected during accessibility audit on learner-facing pages in Workplace. This is actually caused by the fact that all these three elements have the same id. This happens in the forms with dynamic ids that are used in modal and AJAX forms. For example, in vanilla LMS this can be found in the reportbuilder filter form.
I was also able to reproduce this in Moodle 3.9.2.
Safari appears to ignore these enhancements (in 3.9.3).
changing the class _sr-only_ to _d-none_ makes the multichoice questions (radio button) not keyboard accessible

Collaborative Solution Design.source_text: I did a quick try adding a "presentation" or "none" role for fieldset tags that don't have legends.
I would suggest something a bit more meaningful such as "Form actions" instead of "Action buttons".
I think it makes sense for them to be within a fieldset. I haven't looked at the other issue, but can't we add a "{{sr-only}}" label for the fieldset's legend instead?
should we consider whether it is better to maintain the consistency, and only make the change when we are able to do it in all the drag-drop qtypes at once?
I think you can use the font awesome lightbulb version...so it gives a better contrast and set it up so it is white on the hover state with darker backgrounds
Option 1: Update \get_html_lang_attribute_value() to use the iso6391 langconfig string
I agree that displaying a text equivalent to the checkbox's value like "Yes" / "No" will make it more accessible for users.
[~cameron1729] we do need to address the contrast issue on the upgrade pages for accessibility compliance. However as stated the changes need to be restricted to only those pages.
This also far reaching and does't just address the problematic page but appeares to affect every page in the system. Any change should be restricted to the upgrade pages only.
we remove the </body> and </html> and emit these in the shutdown handler if the page is long running.
two separate regex'es extract the body and html after the theme has done its footer render
stash them in a buffer for the shutdown handler
using OUTPUT in the shutdown handler should be ok as long as it checks that it exists and is ready first
The new version follows the conventions with the reactive pattern
[~jpataleta] in this case isn't that image purely decorative? would it not be better to mark it as such for usability reasons?

I suggest the following titles

1. _View mode -_  Course: [Course name]

2. _Edit mode_ - Edit course: [Course name]

3. _Bulk edit mode_ - Bulk edit course: [Course name]

The part in italics is not part of the title, hopefully I make it more clear now:
 # View mode ---> Course: [Course name] 
 # Edit mode ---> Edit course: [Course name]
 # Bulk edit mode ---> Bulk edit course [Course name]
I prefer the style of Docusaurus, with a light grey background and black text.
I've added the UX proposal to the description along with a screenshot of the color contrast checker using the proposed new tone.
a single general styling fix should fix the issue for all drop-downs
theme_boost_union has the desired feature (using scrollspy).
double-scrollbars are the least worst problem
What could be improved is removing the option when you first create a text field.
There are a couple of coding styles violation in the new patch: {{$rtl_status}} is not a valid variable name as underscores are not permitted.
you are changing the icon by changing the font awesome class which does the work but I think that would not be acceptable, we need to change the icons using the same moodle pix icon reference
I have removed the 'legend' tag (from element-header.mustache)
To fix the passwordunmask error, the 'for' attribute is removed when the input is hidden and added back when the input is password.
I recommend the new icon be *fa-cloud-upload* (my preference) or *fa-upload* to represent upload.
Another solution might be to detach these skiplinks from the drawer and adding them after the body tag using JavaScript
I've prepared a patch to remove these spaces: * git fetch git@github.com:sarjona/moodle.git MDL-72674-master-fix && git merge --no-ff FETCH_HEAD
I was just wondering if we should fix this issue in a general way. (In core/modal).
I have created a demo branch that describes my solution.
I do not follow why you have made changes to the underlaying aria role structure within the navigation
Kicking this back to dev as you should remove aria-current since we are changing it to aria-selected.
I personally think that focusBackOnMoreMenu does not need to be a function as it is only called once
Please remove unrequired usages of template literals
I don't think you need to set the tabindex attribute here
Thanks for proposing a fix for the failures #2 and #3... I'm going to launch a couple of jobs (boost and classic) based on it
I think that is the label we should be adding in the qtype_essay renderer (but from a UI point of view, I think it should be sr-only).
Is aria-lable on the ul really the best approach to labeling them? What about an appropriate heading instead?
Should this be refactored so there is a core_renderer method for this - listed in the component library - which every uses.
I would also advise renaming these to nextstep and previousstep. There are no steps here!
The thing is that I'm convinced it would be possible to write the code like this
we already have the code for this, but we would like to know if there is some interest that we share it?
The only thing I'd mention is that I wonder whether this should be: if (this.hasIcon && this.hasChildren()) {
One way of showing pass/fail grades is showing a tick or a cross next to them, or perhaps adding a new column to the table
It looks like perhaps the .text-muted class needs the colour tweaked just a little bit to meet contrast requirements.
Judging from the screenshot, it seems just adding a white background to all buttons with class .btn-outline-secondary should fix the issue.
Bas kindly helped me here and provided a patch which seems to resolve my previously stated issue.
Can you give a code example of how this helps with attributes such as aria-label?
Shouldn't we really be changing the old elements that are currently sending through rendered HTML to the template to instead just send the information to then be sent to a partial?
I agree in that having that link is redundant but the underlying functionality dictates that is how user images are rendered out everywhere
we can just remove the link in case it point to the current page
alt should always be 'picture of John Smith' no matter what they write as the description.
Get rid of left/right layout with the grey info box (this is better on smaller screens anyway).
I can share the CSS if it helps (although a lot of the necessary CSS is undoing all the styling that the core themes apply.)
attached are two files. Probably the bits you need are at the top of question.css. Attaching mod_quiz.css in case anything there is important.
we could comment out the test and I'll add a commit to 66979 to uncomment it.
I think that we should provide a h1 title for the page.
can you please update the patch to group the blocks together into a h2 and then give each individual block an h3?
using H2 block headings is simpler and aligns with the way Twitter handles this.
IN short, IMO, should be put to unlimited.
Only the <a> element is _actually_ a focusable element, so that's the one that we want to target.
Before we integrate this, do you think we can tweak the tabbed navigation to make it distinct from looking like buttons? I'm happy to share ideas with you if you like.
[~basbrands] has prepared the following patch for fixing the issues with Moodle 3.8
We should not need to have both d-none class and aria-hidden="true" at the same time.
My recommendation would be to have a list of links appear at the top of the form which link the user to one or more errors in the form.
integration of small incremental fixes evolves Moodle into something better much quicker than waiting for someone to come along
Here is a fix for the scrollbar overflow issue: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/commit/fae7df7a5be3602f0fdabe2189b0be1a4ed11abd

IMHO this patch is fine as-is using the sr-only tag, but we really should raise a new issue to add headings to the output and, when we do so we would need to make these aria-hidden, and to use the labelled-by anyway.
Perhpas the only real solution here is to move away from using the <label> tag, and instead start using aria-labelled-by attribute or similar pointing at the choice text?

Process Guidance and Knowledge Sharing.source_text: you may wish to rebase your PULL branches to simplify history and avoid any possible merge conflicts.
Colour-blind users do not use screen readers. So using aria attributes are not going to help them at all.
Please make sure that any version.php file on your patch is properly bumped up as well.
Thanks for investigating those failure Sam, I'm launching new Behat builds on this.
Unholding this as it is a must-fix.
Thanks Kerry for suggesting this improvement. I'm just updating the issue summary and description to clarify how it is in standard Moodle.
it would be great if in future similar issues manual tests are added for all Moodle front-ends supporting this feature, including the mobile app

Please remember that renderers are an API. Themes may override them and depend on the current HTML. herefore, significant changes should be documented in upgrade.txt files. (Open Univsity have had serious breakage recently caused by undocumented change in course format stuff on 'stable' branches. I am sure none of us want to cause that again!) ... but I wrote this before reading all the changes.
I'd vote to not backport this fix to 3.11, not only that but we had to add all this new code to get around the problem of rendering the expand/collapse icons in css
We have voted on unholding this issue and agreed that it is ok to break the freeze!
It wouldn't probably be too hard to backport this to 310 and 311, too‚Ä¶ The actual versions could benefit from this as well.
can you, please, rebase the branches, specially 310_STABLE, we are getting there some behat failures which were fixed some good weeks ago.
This has been in integration for a while now. Is there something we can do to help it get integrated?
Please, review git history and leave only strictly required commits here... And don't forget to prepare proper testing instructions for checking what you have changed in the patch
The testing instructions are not very self-explanatory. It is impossible to see what quiz settings are in use.
Hi [~dobedobedoh], could you please PR the code fix? Thanks
Can we please consider this issue for 3.9 as it is part of our work to improve accessibility across Moodle.
These improvements will be master only so ok to integrate.
These improvements will be master only so ok to integrate.
I know accessibility fixes are important, but is this really the type of change that should land on a 'Stable' branch? This is definitely an API change.
Could you be more explicit and precise on what to focus and what to verify?
Can you update the test instructions on this issue to explain that more precisely?
it would be great to improve the testing instructions to cover more scenarios.
We recommend to make the insert + delete a transaction ($DB->start_delegated_transaction() / $transaction->allow_commit();)
Andrew recommended that I create an issue about it, here it is MDL-68657
Also, I agree that in this case, it is OK not to backport to 3.11.
